Ann Sothern had a successful career as both an actress and a singer.

Ann Sothern was not only known for her versatile acting skills but also had a beautiful singing voice. She showcased her talent in various musical films and even released several music albums during her career.

She was born as Harriet Lake.

Before she became known as Ann Sothern, she was born as Harriet Lake on January 22, 1909, in Valley City, North Dakota. She later adopted her stage name to pursue her acting career.

Ann Sothern starred in the popular sitcom “Private Secretary.”

One of her most memorable roles was playing the lead character, Susie MacNamara, in the hit sitcom “Private Secretary.” The show ran for five seasons, from 1953 to 1957, and gained Sothern widespread recognition.

She was nominated for an Academy Award for her role in “The Whales of August.”

In 1988, Sothern received critical acclaim for her performance as Libby Strong in the film “The Whales of August.” This earned her a nomination for Best Supporting Actress at the 61st Academy Awards.

Ann Sothern was a contract star for MGM.

During the 1940s, Sothern signed a contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM) Studios, which catapulted her career. She appeared in numerous successful films under the MGM banner.

She won a Golden Globe for her role in the television series “The Ann Sothern Show.”

For her portrayal of Katy O’Connor in the sitcom “The Ann Sothern Show,” she received a Golden Globe Award for Best TV Star – Female in 1959.

Ann Sothern voiced the character of Aunt Fanny in the animated film “A Bug’s Life.”

In 1998, Sothern lent her voice to the lovable character Aunt Fanny in the Disney-Pixar film “A Bug’s Life.” Her performance added charm and warmth to the animated feature.

She was a staunch advocate for animal rights.

Sothern was a passionate animal lover and dedicated much of her time to advocating for animal rights. She actively supported organizations such as the Humane Society of the United States.

She starred in the popular film series “Maisie.”

Sothern portrayed the character of Maisie Ravier in a series of ten films during the 1930s and 1940s. The films followed the adventures of Maisie, a brassy yet endearing showgirl.

Ann Sothern had a successful stage career.

Aside from her accomplishments in film and television, Sothern also had a successful stage career. She made her Broadway debut in “The Red Velvet Goat” in 1958 and continued to perform on stage throughout her life.

She was married three times.

Throughout her life, Sothern was married three times. Her first marriage was to Roger Pryor, followed by Robert Sterling, and finally, to Robert L. Stevens, with whom she remained married until her passing in 2001.
